abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and the institutional
            development impact substantial. Nonetheless, several lessons
            indicate that : 1) poverty targeting needs to be improved,
            to include an approval criteria on the types of
            micro-projects. This would require a revised methodology,
            formulated on the share of population, and the degree of
            poverty; a revised approval criteria based on infrastructure
            conditions, cost per beneficiary, and capacity of the
            implementing agency; and, changes in the micro-projects
            typology to reflect community demands; 2) improvement of
            inter-sectoral, and inter-agency coordination needs to focus
            on consistent social fund activities, at par with relevant
            social policies, and investment priorities. This would
            require the development of effective information strategies,
            and regular working contacts with the Government, the Bank,
            and donors; 3) the quality of work needs improvement, to
            ensure the inclusion of technical specifications for all
            micro-project types, and a well defined procurement process,
            which would require training of contractors, as well as
            assistance from advisory services; and, 4) additionally,
            local capacity, and, monitoring and evaluation needs further
            improvement. Other issues call for more decentralized
            decision making, the need to match Fund arrangements, and,
            to refine micro-project calculations, and cost effectiveness.
